text: So the ValOS resource model consists of Resources, which have a specific URI. These are Entities, Relations or Medias. The basic example is an Entity which contains some Properties. Any changes to either Entities or their Properties are automatically transferred to any subscribed clients, and listenable by code.

elements.text: So the ValOS resource model consists of Resources, which have a specific URI. These are Entities, Relations or Medias. The basic example is an Entity which contains some Properties. Any changes to either Entities or their Properties are automatically transferred to any subscribed clients, and listenable by code.

text: same kinda thing then

elements.text: same kinda thing then

text: The change propagation does not (currently, at least) use P2P network, but instead some Authority owns any Resource, and the Authority handles the data transfers.

elements.text: The change propagation does not (currently, at least) use P2P network, but instead some Authority owns any Resource, and the Authority handles the data transfers.

text: But I'm also working hard on readability. That's why I'm designing an IDE at the same time, so that I can do things like automatically insert readability text into functions, like numfunRandom(random number between 0.00 and 1.00).

text: The basic model for handling data consistency in ValOS (currently) is that when something changes, the Gateway (client) makes the change to its own model, then sends that change to the Authority. Once the Authority responds with an "ok" then the Gateway will mark that change as a Truth. If the Authority responds with a failure the Gateway will remove the change. Depending on the type of failure, the Gateway might then retry, or just leave the state unchanged.

elements.text: The basic model for handling data consistency in ValOS (currently) is that when something changes, the Gateway (client) makes the change to its own model, then sends that change to the Authority. Once the Authority responds with an "ok" then the Gateway will mark that change as a Truth. If the Authority responds with a failure the Gateway will remove the change. Depending on the type of failure, the Gateway might then retry, or just leave the state unchanged.

text: (i.e. no strict function name first syntax, etc)

elements.text: (i.e. no strict function name first syntax, etc)

text: If there's a data connection problem, the Gateway will store the changes in a queue and work as-if connected, and once the connection is restored it'll send all the changed to the Authority.

elements.text: If there's a data connection problem, the Gateway will store the changes in a queue and work as-if connected, and once the connection is restored it'll send all the changed to the Authority.

text: ok .. Onex is much more relaxed than that!

text: Onex has a best effort and could fail philosophy, the lowest level of reliability, since you need to cater for cases where you actually don't care if data is updated in a timely way

elements.text: Onex has a best effort and could fail philosophy, the lowest level of reliability, since you need to cater for cases where you actually don't care if data is updated in a timely way

text: then build reliability on top, using timeouts, at the user programming level

text: If the Authority has in the meantime already received other changes, then it'll just reject, and the Gateway will fetch the latest changes and reapply its own things on top of the latest changes (unless there are conflicts).

elements.text: If the Authority has in the meantime already received other changes, then it'll just reject, and the Gateway will fetch the latest changes and reapply its own things on top of the latest changes (unless there are conflicts).

text: So basically when you read from one of our current authorities you get the data as you do, and any changes you make are sent to the Authority. But when you read from Onex object it fetches its data, and making any changes sends (or attempts to send) the changes to that Object.

elements.text: So basically when you read from one of our current authorities you get the data as you do, and any changes you make are sent to the Authority. But when you read from Onex object it fetches its data, and making any changes sends (or attempts to send) the changes to that Object.

text: There's also another layer of interoperability - the ruleset model. It would be possible to use ValOS resource model for building the Onex ruleset (the stuff in the spreadsheets) and then send that to the Object (as converted into the Onex format). Not sure what the use would be since you already have a ruleset designer, but could be an interesting experiment at some point.

elements.text: There's also another layer of interoperability - the ruleset model. It would be possible to use ValOS resource model for building the Onex ruleset (the stuff in the spreadsheets) and then send that to the Object (as converted into the Onex format). Not sure what the use would be since you already have a ruleset designer, but could be an interesting experiment at some point.
